content.question: Spark Streaming: How do I read from multiple topics in the same Spark Session
content.content:
To read from multiple topics in the same Spark session, follow these steps:

1. **Initiate a Spark Session:**
   
   ```python
   spark = (SparkSession
       .builder
       .appName(app_name)
       .master(master=master)
       .getOrCreate())
   
   spark.streams.resetTerminated()
   ```

2. **Read Streams from Multiple Topics:**
   
   ```python
   query1 = spark
       .readStream
       ...
       ...
       .load()
   
   query2 = spark
       .readStream
       ...
       ...
       .load()
   
   query3 = spark
       .readStream
       ...
       ...
       .load()
   ```

3. **Start the Queries:**
   
   ```python
   query1.start()
   query2.start()
   query3.start()
   ```

4. **Await Termination:**
   
   ```python
   spark.streams.awaitAnyTermination()  # Waits for any one of the queries to receive a kill signal or error failure. This is asynchronous.
   ```

   Note: `query3.start().awaitTermination()` is a blocking call. It works well when we are reading only from one topic.

content.question: Edit Course Profile.
content.content:
The display name listed on the leaderboard is an auto-generated randomized name. You can edit it to be a nickname or your real name if you prefer. Your entry on the Leaderboard is the one highlighted in light green.

The Certificate name should be your actual name that you want to appear on your certificate after completing the course.

The "Display on Leaderboard" option indicates whether you want your name to be listed on the course leaderboard.

content.question: Course: When does the course start?
content.content:
The next cohort starts January 13th, 2025. More info at [DTC](https://datatalks.club/blog/guide-to-free-online-courses-at-datatalks-club.html).

- Register before the course starts using this [link](https://airtable.com/shr6oVXeQvSI5HuWD).
- Join the [course Telegram channel with announcements](https://t.me/dezoomcamp).
- Don’t forget to register in DataTalks.Club's Slack and join the channel.

content.question: Certificate - Can I follow the course in a self-paced mode and get a certificate?
content.content: No, you can only get a certificate if you finish the course with a “live” cohort. We don't award certificates for the self-paced mode. The reason is you need to peer-review capstone(s) after submitting a project. You can only peer-review projects at the time the course is running.

content.question: Course - Can I follow the course after it finishes?
content.content:
Yes, we will keep all the materials available, so you can follow the course at your own pace after it finishes.

You can also continue reviewing the homeworks and prepare for the next cohort. You can also start working on your final capstone project.

content.question: Course: What can I do before the course starts?
content.content:
Start by installing and setting up all the dependencies and requirements:

- Google Cloud account
- Google Cloud SDK
- Python 3 (installed with Anaconda)
- Terraform
- Git

Look over the prerequisites and syllabus to see if you are comfortable with these subjects.

content.question: How do I use Git / GitHub for this course?
content.content:
After you create a GitHub account, clone the course repo to your local machine using the process outlined in this video:

[Git for Everybody: How to Clone a Repository from GitHub](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CKcqniGu3tA).

Having this local repository on your computer will make it easy to access the instructors’ code and make pull requests if you want to add your own notes or make changes to the course content.

You will probably also create your own repositories to host your notes and versions of files. Here is a great tutorial that shows you how to do this:

[How to Create a Git Repository](https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/setting-up-a-repository).

Remember to ignore large databases, .csv, and .gz files, and other files that should not be saved to a repository. Use `.gitignore` for this:

[.gitignore file](https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/saving-changes/gitignore).

**Important:**

**NEVER store passwords or keys in a git repo** (even if the repo is set to private). Put files containing sensitive information (.env, secret.json, etc.) in your `.gitignore`.

This is also a great resource: [Dangit, Git!?!](https://dangitgit.com/)

parts.content:
It seems I couldn't find specific documentation on the exact topics you will learn by joining the course. However, I can provide general guidance on what to expect.

Typically, a course in this domain may cover a range of topics including:

1. **Introduction to Data Engineering Concepts**: Understanding data pipelines, data warehousing, and data modeling.
2. **Tools and Technologies**: Familiarity with data processing frameworks like Apache Spark and data storage solutions such as SQL and NoSQL databases.
3. **Data Streaming**: Learning about real-time data processing and stream handling techniques.
4. **Cloud Platforms**: Usage of cloud services like Google Cloud for data management and deployment.
5. **ETL Processes**: Techniques for Extracting, Transforming, and Loading data.
6. **Project Work**: Hands-on capstone projects that apply what you've learned in a practical context.

For the most accurate and detailed information regarding course content, I recommend checking the course syllabus or directly referring to the [DataTalksClub FAQ](https://github.com/DataTalksClub/faq/blob/main/).

If you have any specific questions or need further assistance, feel free to ask!
